00020   /**
00021    * \brief %Geocentric coordinates
00022    *
00023    * Convert between geodetic coordinates latitude = \e lat, longitude = \e
00024    * lon, height = \e h (measured vertically from the surface of the ellipsoid)
00025    * to geocentric coordinates (\e X, \e Y, \e Z).  The origin of geocentric
00026    * coordinates is at the center of the earth.  The \e Z axis goes thru the
00027    * north pole, \e lat = 90<sup>o</sup>.  The \e X axis goes thru \e lat = 0,
00028    * \e lon = 0.  %Geocentric coordinates are also known as earth centered,
00029    * earth fixed (ECEF) coordinates.
00030    *
00031    * The conversion from geographic to geocentric coordinates is
00032    * straightforward.  For the reverse transformation we use
00033    * - H. Vermeille,
00034    *   <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00190-002-0273-6"> Direct
00035    *   transformation from geocentric coordinates to geodetic coordinates</a>,
00036    *   J. Geodesy 76, 451&ndash;454 (2002).
00037    * .
00038    * Several changes have been made to ensure that the method returns accurate
00039    * results for all finite inputs (even if \e h is infinite).  The changes are
00040    * described in Appendix B of
00041    * - C. F. F. Karney,
00042    *   <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">Geodesics
00043    *   on an ellipsoid of revolution</a>,
00044    *   Feb. 2011;
00045    *   preprint
00046    *   <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">arxiv:1102.1215v1</a>.
00047    * .
00048    * See \ref geocentric for more information.
00049    *
00050    * The errors in these routines are close to round-off.  Specifically, for
00051    * points within 5000 km of the surface of the ellipsoid (either inside or
00052    * outside the ellipsoid), the error is bounded by 7 nm (7 nanometers) for
00053    * the WGS84 ellipsoid.  See \ref geocentric for further information on the
00054    * errors.
00055    *
00056    * Example of use:
00057    * \include example-Geocentric.cpp
00058    **********************************************************************/
00059 
00060   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT Geocentric {
00061   private:
00062     typedef Math::real real;
00063     friend class LocalCartesian;
00064     friend class MagneticCircle; // MagneticCircle uses Rotation
00065     friend class MagneticModel;  // MagneticModel uses IntForward
00066     friend class GravityCircle;  // GravityCircle uses Rotation
00067     friend class GravityModel;   // GravityModel uses IntForward
00068     friend class NormalGravity;  // NormalGravity uses IntForward
00069     friend class SphericalHarmonic;
00070     friend class SphericalHarmonic1;
00071     friend class SphericalHarmonic2;
00072     static const size_t dim_ = 3;
00073     static const size_t dim2_ = dim_ * dim_;
00074     real _a, _f, _e2, _e2m, _e2a, _e4a, _maxrad;
00075     static void Rotation(real sphi, real cphi, real slam, real clam,
00076                          real M[dim2_]) throw();
00077     static void Rotate(real M[dim2_], real x, real y, real z,
00078                        real& X, real& Y, real& Z) throw() {
00079       // Perform [X,Y,Z]^t = M.[x,y,z]^t
00080       // (typically local cartesian to geocentric)
00081       X = M[0] * x + M[1] * y + M[2] * z;
00082       Y = M[3] * x + M[4] * y + M[5] * z;
00083       Z = M[6] * x + M[7] * y + M[8] * z;
00084     }
00085     static void Unrotate(real M[dim2_], real X, real Y, real Z,
00086                          real& x, real& y, real& z) throw()  {
00087       // Perform [x,y,z]^t = M^t.[X,Y,Z]^t
00088       // (typically geocentric to local cartesian)
00089       x = M[0] * X + M[3] * Y + M[6] * Z;
00090       y = M[1] * X + M[4] * Y + M[7] * Z;
00091       z = M[2] * X + M[5] * Y + M[8] * Z;
00092     }
00093     void IntForward(real lat, real lon, real h, real& X, real& Y, real& Z,
00094                     real M[dim2_]) const throw();
00095     void IntReverse(real X, real Y, real Z, real& lat, real& lon, real& h,
00096                     real M[dim2_]) const throw();
00097 
00098   public:
00099 
00100     /**
00101      * Constructor for a ellipsoid with
00102      *
00103      * @param[in] a equatorial radius (meters).
00104      * @param[in] f flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e f = 0 gives a sphere.
00105      *   Negative \e f gives a prolate ellipsoid.  If \e f > 1, set flattening
00106      *   to 1/\e f.
00107      *
00108      * An exception is thrown if either of the axes of the ellipsoid is
00109      * non-positive.
00110      **********************************************************************/
00111     Geocentric(real a, real f);
00112 
00113     /**
00114      * A default constructor (for use by NormalGravity).
00115      **********************************************************************/
00116     Geocentric() : _a(-1) {}
00117 
00118     /**
00119      * Convert from geodetic to geocentric coordinates.
00120      *
00121      * @param[in] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00122      * @param[in] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00123      * @param[in] h height of point above the ellipsoid (meters).
00124      * @param[out] X geocentric coordinate (meters).
00125      * @param[out] Y geocentric coordinate (meters).
00126      * @param[out] Z geocentric coordinate (meters).
00127      *
00128      * \e lat should be in the range [-90, 90]; \e lon and \e lon0 should be in
00129      * the range [-180, 360].
00130      **********************************************************************/
00131     void Forward(real lat, real lon, real h, real& X, real& Y, real& Z)
00132       const throw() {
00133       if (Init())
00134         IntForward(lat, lon, h, X, Y, Z, NULL);
00135     }
00136 
00137     /**
00138      * Convert from geodetic to geocentric coordinates and return rotation
00139      * matrix.
00140      *
00141      * @param[in] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00142      * @param[in] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00143      * @param[in] h height of point above the ellipsoid (meters).
00144      * @param[out] X geocentric coordinate (meters).
00145      * @param[out] Y geocentric coordinate (meters).
00146      * @param[out] Z geocentric coordinate (meters).
00147      * @param[out] M if the length of the vector is 9, fill with the rotation
00148      *   matrix in row-major order.
00149      *
00150      * Let \e v be a unit vector located at (\e lat, \e lon, \e h).  We can
00151      * express \e v as \e column vectors in one of two ways
00152      * - in east, north, up coordinates (where the components are relative to a
00153      *   local coordinate system at (\e lat, \e lon, \e h)); call this
00154      *   representation \e v1.
00155      * - in geocentric \e X, \e Y, \e Z coordinates; call this representation
00156      *   \e v0.
00157      * .
00158      * Then we have \e v0 = \e M . \e v1.
00159      **********************************************************************/
00160     void Forward(real lat, real lon, real h, real& X, real& Y, real& Z,
00161                  std::vector<real>& M)
00162       const throw() {
00163       if (!Init())
00164         return;
00165       if (M.end() == M.begin() + dim2_) {
00166         real t[dim2_];
00167         IntForward(lat, lon, h, X, Y, Z, t);
00168         copy(t, t + dim2_, M.begin());
00169       } else
00170         IntForward(lat, lon, h, X, Y, Z, NULL);
00171     }
00172 
00173     /**
00174      * Convert from geocentric to geodetic to coordinates.
00175      *
00176      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate (meters).
00177      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate (meters).
00178      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate (meters).
00179      * @param[out] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00180      * @param[out] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00181      * @param[out] h height of point above the ellipsoid (meters).
00182      *
00183      * In general there are multiple solutions and the result which maximizes
00184      * \e h is returned.  If there are still multiple solutions with different
00185      * latitudes (applies only if \e Z = 0), then the solution with \e lat > 0
00186      * is returned.  If there are still multiple solutions with different
00187      * longitudes (applies only if \e X = \e Y = 0) then \e lon = 0 is
00188      * returned.  The value of \e h returned satisfies \e h >= - \e a (1 -
00189      * <i>e</i><sup>2</sup>) / sqrt(1 - <i>e</i><sup>2</sup> sin<sup>2</sup>\e
00190      * lat).  The value of \e lon returned is in the range [-180, 180).
00191      **********************************************************************/
00192     void Reverse(real X, real Y, real Z, real& lat, real& lon, real& h)
00193       const throw() {
00194       if (Init())
00195         IntReverse(X, Y, Z, lat, lon, h, NULL);
00196     }
00197 
00198     /**
00199      * Convert from geocentric to geodetic to coordinates.
00200      *
00201      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate (meters).
00202      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate (meters).
00203      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate (meters).
00204      * @param[out] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00205      * @param[out] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00206      * @param[out] h height of point above the ellipsoid (meters).
00207      * @param[out] M if the length of the vector is 9, fill with the rotation
00208      *   matrix in row-major order.
00209      *
00210      * Let \e v be a unit vector located at (\e lat, \e lon, \e h).  We can
00211      * express \e v as \e column vectors in one of two ways
00212      * - in east, north, up coordinates (where the components are relative to a
00213      *   local coordinate system at (\e lat, \e lon, \e h)); call this
00214      *   representation \e v1.
00215      * - in geocentric \e X, \e Y, \e Z coordinates; call this representation
00216      *   \e v0.
00217      * .
00218      * Then we have \e v1 = \e M^T . \e v0, where \e M^T is the transpose of \e
00219      * M.
00220      **********************************************************************/
00221     void Reverse(real X, real Y, real Z, real& lat, real& lon, real& h,
00222                  std::vector<real>& M)
00223       const throw() {
00224       if (!Init())
00225         return;
00226       if (M.end() == M.begin() + dim2_) {
00227         real t[dim2_];
00228         IntReverse(X, Y, Z, lat, lon, h, t);
00229         copy(t, t + dim2_, M.begin());
00230       } else
00231         IntReverse(X, Y, Z, lat, lon, h, NULL);
00232     }
00233 
00234     /** \name Inspector functions
00235      **********************************************************************/
00236     ///@{
00237     /**
00238      * @return true if the object has been initialized.
00239      **********************************************************************/
00240     bool Init() const throw() { return _a > 0; }
00241     /**
00242      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00243      *   the value used in the constructor.
00244      **********************************************************************/
00245     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw()
00246     { return Init() ? _a : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00247 
00248     /**
00249      * @return \e f the  flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is the
00250      *   value used in the constructor.
00251      **********************************************************************/
00252     Math::real Flattening() const throw()
00253     { return Init() ? _f : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00254 
00255     /**
00256      * <b>DEPRECATED</b>
00257      * @return \e r the inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.
00258      **********************************************************************/
00259     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw()
00260     { return Init() ? 1/_f : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00261     ///@}
00262 
00263     /**
00264      * A global instantiation of Geocentric with the parameters for the WGS84
00265      * ellipsoid.
00266      **********************************************************************/
00267     static const Geocentric WGS84;
00268   };
00269 
00270 } // namespace GeographicLib
